												I love fishing, it has become one of my favorite things todo besides gaming. Sadly this game does a horrible job at even attempting at the genre.I want to start with the most important stuff.. Is this game a cash grab? Or a p2w mess? It's both.First off you can buy items to upgrade your gear off the bat. The market place is full of overpriced cosmetics for your character that looks sorta like a every game from 2005, but cosmetics are not p2w at all. Well there is an "upgrading" RNG style that requires items you can buy from the market place for that sole purpose, with the odds of failing causing you to lose a + on said items (+2 Rod fails to +3, turns into +1 Rod etc)Now how will P2W be a problem in a fishing game? Well if all you want to do is fish.. and nothing competitive then sure it delivers that.. oh wait did I mention most items are rented? Including items in the market place that you pay real cash for end up vanishing after 7/15/30 days etc, so it kinda means that if you don't use said items you spent real cash for.. it goes to waste, obligating you to continue playing because of investments.. But then the upgrading comes into play too.. say there are some sort of tornaments/events being ran at the time.. guess who will probably win? The guy who is spending hundreds on his gear and boat etc etc.Now that the important stuff is out of the way lets go into the other non important stuff (my opinion)The graphics are horrible. This game has such dated graphics that it just had to be some sort of cash grab on the fishing market.. honestly get past all those fancy looking screenshots and actually try the game. That's about it for the graphics.The UI is just plain bad and unresponsive, there seems to be lag between anything you want to do. Even putting an item on gives you a prompt to wait for some reason.. (I feel like this game failed previously because of some duping due to this mechanic.)The music well.. it's a fishing game.. you probably wouldn't want to listen to elevator music while you play anyway so expect the same MIDI file over and over.Overall if you can live without the p2w and rented items, and the bad UI.. and you enjoy fishing games.. then by all means go for it. I honestly like the game and am willing to look past the UI but I just can't get involved with p2w games. I also greatly dislike the renting mechanic used in many free games.

												Okay, here's the scoop, it's a fairly fun game at the start, but as time goes along it gets very old very quickly. I hate to be the, free2play but pay2win, guy, but there is a valid argument to be had there. I could live with that but, in all honesty, it's more like pay to play. they do a fine job early on of disguising this fact with free items awarded from quests. the first week or 2 you have access to a few "pearl" boats as quest rewards, and plenty of fuel because the quest reward boats (also available for purchase with real world money) get roughly 5 times  the fuel economy of the standard boats bought with in game currency. Once your lvl 30 free "pearl" boat disapears, that's it your on your own, and you go from using maybe 1 gas can every hour or so to needing 3 gas cans just to get to the far side of ONE area. You can spend a bit of real money and get a pearl boat and an upgraded version of you fishing equipment, (rod and reel), and then your set right.....I'm afraid not....They have a limited use, they are not "timed" as ppl balked at the idea of paying real money for an item that dissapears after 30 days. so instead they have a certain amount of "health". When that health has been depleted, it is not useable any more unless you get a repair kit, which only cost about 10 days worth of daily quest rewards, unfortunately it only takes about a week to burn up your equipment if you play many hours daily, which you will  do if you want to accomplish anything. so one repair kit every 9-10 days, which is enough to repair one item about halfway, ...you have three pcs of equipment you can't leave the dock to go fishing without, that all need repaired. it's pretty easy math.... you ain't gonna keep up, of course the only way to get fuel without whipping out the credit card is to use those daily rewards, so you won't likely be able to get more than one repair kit a month.I like the game concept, as i am a completionist and a collector, but the money grab here is just a bit more than i'm willing to get into.I miss the good old days when a game was payed for one time and then you had access to the entirety of the game.I would spend a bit of money here because i enjoy the game, but i am not going to start dumping cash down a  bottomless money pit.I realize that these game companies are in the business of making money, not providing me free entertainment, ....but there are honest and upfront ways to go about doing that, you won't find those here.just my take on things, and others' thoughts may vary.

												Actually a real fun fishing game. Especially once you get used to the mechanics.I've been playing for a few days and just hit level 22. Here's my thoughts and advice:1. The questing system is designed where you must activate (accept) each one before you can fish for the requirements. And there's a limit of 15 active quests at a time.First, activate all of the daily quests. You get free fuel and c-coins.Second, determine where you will fish and accept all quests that correspond with that location.Third, go to the location and open your mini-map. Go to 'quests', toggle each of them off and on to see which area on the map would reap the most quest objectives and drive your boat to that spot.Fourth, go fish.2. Do not buy fish hooks from the store. You can get these from the fortune cards that are randomly rewarded while fishing.3. Do the Sudden Mission quests (the timed ones that pop up).4. Don't try to fish beyond your level. You'll deplete your resources. I focused on the first location and completing the Fish Wiki for it before moving to the second location.And I still have over 60 fuel tanks and countless underwater cams (which I haven't even used since the tutorial).5. When fishing, it's all about timing. The best way to get a catch is to after casting, position your view (with right mouse button) to where you can see the floater. You want to aim to yank the hook right when the floater gets pulled completely underwater.And when swinging, do it in the opposite direction the fish is swimming.If you manage to stun the fish, don't bother swinging again. Just release tension to bring it out of the red and continue reeling.If the fish swims towards the boat try to move out of the way: left side - press "A", right side - press "D". If it heads straight for the nose... lol. Sorry.6. Another FAQ I see is where/how to sell the fish?To sell fish, you have to be at the dock. At the dock, simply open your livewell and you'll see te option to sell them.Keep in mind that some quests may require you to turn in a fish. Be sure not to sell any of those or you'll have to recatch them.Most quests, however, only require you to catch the fish and are safe to be sold (or released) after catching.7. A personal preference: I turn the music from the game all the way down as I find it a bit annoying.And then I open Spotify and play an offline playlist in the background while running the game.8. A lot of the hiccups the game had on launch were from the understimated demand for this type of game on Steam. The first day, the servers were pushed beyond their limits because there just isn't a quality fishing game on Steam.Since then, they've stabilized the servers and things are running much smoother now.9. One thing I do dislike is having to retype my e-mail and password every time I launch the game to log in. It would be nice if it at least remembered the e-mail.On the bright side, this is a game that a second person can play on the same computer with a different profile without worry of them accidentally gimping yours.10. You'll notice that sessions are on two hour timers. This is undoubtedly to deter people from camping. This is actually a good thing because each room (or session) has a limit of number of players.However, as beautiful as the game is... you're not pressured to fish and you can waste a few minutes just chatting and enjoying the visuals (which has really good weather dynamics and ambient sounds).Two hours is plenty of time, anyway, to fish.Of course, if the timer runs out you just spawn back in the room lobby and launch another two-hour session. No biggie.All in all, I would say that this is a really polished fishing game and I really enjoy it. Two worms up!

												This is pretty much a repackaging / port of an old fishing MMO by name of Fishing Hero. But do not let the failure of the previous title make you think this game is not worth playing because it is strangely addictive and thrilling.Pros: 919 total catchable fish as of the time I am writing this review on 2016/11/15. I love that each fish has its own unique textures and way of swimming / fighting. I absolutely adore the level of details that each map holds. And it has one of the very few music backgrounds that I can listen to for hours without wanting to shoot myself. Extremely addictive trying to catch the biggest fish of each species, and needing to find the best fishing areas for each specific species. The weather varies and brings realistic changes in the fish behavior causing certain species to become more or less aggressive for example. A wide variety of maps to fish each with their own fish unique to that map makes for an amazing experience. Fish bite the bait fairly quickly so no boredom waiting for a strike unlike the real fishing world. PvP is fun rather than stressful because there are no losers as everyone gets awarded for participating. Players do not "compete" for spawns. Each spawned fish is unique to the angler putting the bait into the water, and boats don't bump into each other or interfere with each other's catch attempts. An aquarium feature that allows you to save some of your catches and even turn them into a monitor screensaver.Cons: There are some bugs still in the current version of the game, including a nasty one with the Holding feature occasionally causing fish to teleport. There is a deliberate line of code in the game that causes a fish to instantly become insanely unlikely to spawn the instant you accept a quest for catching it even while the fish rarity display will say it is very common to be found. Which in turn forces you to artificially hunt fish in the same location for hours just to finish one quest. Boats become deeper and deeper gas guzzlers which practically forces players to PvP at higher levels since its the best way to earn free gas, and to buy gas you need to pay money. Some of the features that were available for Fishing Heroes end life, have not yet been reintroduced to this new version of the game such as night fishing.Neither a Pro nor a Con: Free players can play the game and enjoy it well into their 50s in levels. However purchasing the game currency of "Pearls" will definitely make the game easier for a player since it allows purchase of better statted perma gear among other things. But a free player can play forever without feeling like they are missing out on the experience the pearl players achieve.Finally, I would suggest however that you not put any points into the Endurance stat when levelling up as its a point sink waste. Barely any extra stamina gains from putting points into it, but points in other two stats have a significant impact on damage done or rate that you do damage as well as "skill" usage. It has been consistently proven in-game that players who added Endurance equally to the other stats have a slower experience landing fish based on current fishing dynamics.Overall I am definitely enjoying this game and would recommend it to anyone interested in a fishing game. It could be improved, and hopefully will be, but in its current state its definitely a good game to spend a few hours a day in.

Since this is a shamefully long review, here's the short version:All-in-all, if you want to try out a fun fishing game with a social element, that doesn't take itself too seriously, then I heartily recommend giving World of Fishing a go, even though it is a little rough around the edges.And the long version:Having reached level 30 in-game (lvl 80 is the maximum), I feel I am now in a position to do a little write-up on World of Fishing.To start off, let me say that I feel many reviews on Steam are doing this game a real disservice.  I wish people could take a little time to play a game before writing it off and taking a dump on the developer's hard work.  It must be infuriating to put a lot of effort into trying to make something fun, only to have it unfairly torn to shreds in public.  Anyway, on to my opinion of World of Fishing:The game is a diamond in the rough.Like many, I downloaded it the day it launched on Steam, and yeah, it was a bit of a mess.  Servers were causing trouble, from what I understand.  Some couldn't register an account.  Some couldn't log in after registering.  And if you did log in, the gameplay was hampered by terrible lag.However, it seems the developers have been working hard, and most of these problems are now fixed.  The gameplay is really smooth, with very little lag.Yes, it is a F2P game, and yes you can spend money in-game for upgrades and such.  However, of all the F2P games I have tried, this is one that doesn't require you to fork out tons of money to keep playing.  There are plenty of ways to acquire the things you need.  Some of which you discover as you go along.  Sure, you can burn through cash if you want to, but it is not a necessity and I do not feel held back if I choose to play on the cheap.(Small disclaimer: I have not yet tried the PvP competitive fishing side, so I cannot say whether there is a P2W element there.  I shall update you when I get around to it.)That said, I have spent some money on WoF, because in the end of the day there are people working on the game and they need to eat and even turn a profit on their efforts.  Let's be honest, game development is not a pro bono endeavor.There is a lot of fun to be had in World of Fishing.  Be warned though, it is not a fishing simulator.The gameplay is very much on the arcade side.  To me, this is a plus.  Personally, I do not enjoy fishing in real life, unless I am hungry.  If you want to wait around for ages for something to bite, WoF will probably not be your thing.I do not mean say that WoF is not challenging.  Once you step out of the starter area, you will quickly find fish that behave in unique ways and put up a real fight.  It can be a blast trying to reel in a tough albacore, for example.  You have to maneouver your boat, watch your line tension, top up your stamina with energy drinks, and pull off various combos to wear the thing down.If you like snooping around, there are special types of fish hiding in lots of areas, which contribute to an element of exploration.  When you find one, you will know the second it tears off with your hook, abruptly changes direction, ducks under your boat and snaps your line in a heartbeat, leaving you gaping and wondering what just happened. But try some more and finally catch the thing and you will feel rewarded for persevering.All of your catches can be sold for in-game currency, but you also have the option of storing your favorites in your personal aquarium to admire for as long as you like.There is planning and character leveling involved too.  Just about everything can be upgraded to give you an edge.  You have to stock up on different kinds of bait.  You earn fuel by fulfilling quests to keep your boat going.  And all of it is very enjoyable.  However, some of it does take a while to understand, and the UI is a little clunky.If you can't wrap your head around some game mechanic, then just ask in chat, or on the forums.  The community is helpful and, despite what some have said in their Steam reviews, the moderators and GMs are friendly and welcoming.  Don't be shy.While I do enjoy World of Fishing, it is definitely rough around the edges.The graphics are outdated.  I wouldn't let it detract from the experience though.  I have played a ton of beautiful AAA titles with state-of-the-art graphics, and I would rather exchange a beautiful game for a fun one any day.The music is very silly, and I muted it in a flash.Lastly, there are only 12 character models to choose from.  6 male.  6 female.  And unfortunately, they all look cartoonish.  Which was a little disappointing.  Maybe the devs can bring out more in the future, who knows?Thanks for reading.  Hope it helps.  Maybe see you on the water!polarnomad

The in game currency works just fine for outfitting your character with enough equipment so that they look unique and have stat boosting equipment. Love the RPG element to it by the way. You build your character up, and as they get more XP, they gain more levels, and get access to bigger, better, fish.The only thing I can really naysay at the moment is the lag/crashing/etc that can be expected from a recently launched title. 												World of Fishing is not bad, but then not good either. It is a very simple fishing game in which you cast a line and then spend a while trying to tire out the fish so you can reel it in. The fishing is not realistic in any way, so do not expect a simulator.That said, it would certainly be nice if it had some more depth to it, at times even literally depth- Your bait is always at roughly the same depth, and fish all swim at the same depth. Not that you will notice much of that, you only get limited uses of limited time to look underwater, which is not even useful to you because you have no control over what happens once you have cast but before the fish bites.It is quite repetitive, with almost every fish the same but at a varying difficulty. You cast your line, swipe once and then the fish is hooked(or gets away), at which point you have to try to manage your line's tension to keep the fish struggling. But if the fish gets too far away, or too close your line will immediately break. That said, it is not bad, and you can amuse yourself by turning on some music and just fishing for a while.You can keep fish in your aquarium, so you can look at them any time you want. But your first fish from the tutorial will be released. After that you can keep your fish, but aside from a few very specific quest fish it almost seems pointless- These fish are all similar.Speaking of- Another thing you need to be aware of when you decide to play is that the odds are most likely manipulated when you play. If you get a quest for 3 fish of a specific kind, it will take over 50 fish to find the ones you are after, even if those you are after are marked as very common and you use the perfect bait for them. Not that the bait matters most of the time- As most fish you encounter all take the same bait you generally don't see results from changing it. Overall, the game has a feeling of not letting you effect things, you can only hope for the slightest of chances that things go your way.Since it is free, you will undoubtedly want to know how they make their money. Simple enough, they sell premium items. You may not like the idea, but I can tell you that they are not essential and must-haves. You will not be locked out of things when you don't want to buy them. But that said, they have a noticeable effect compared to your basic free stuff, and quests will provide you with enough to give them a try without having to buy them. Cosmetics wise there is essentially nothing. It is very basic, and you will look similar to everyone else.All this is, essentially, nothing too bad. There is not much to be had here, but also nothing really terrible. If you have time to spend and are bored then give it a go- You won't lose out on anything, but it isn't going to be amazing either.Worth a try sometime to see if you like it, but don't get invested or expect much.

Only a total fool would even pretend to not know about it and ridicule a Canadian of hiding under a U.S. flag.=================================================================ORIGINAL REVIEWTLDR?  Well, your loss.  Seriously though, just scroll to the bottom of this very long runon sentence of a review I made.  It's still probably a long TLDR, but that's the shortest I can make it.  I talk too much... I know.I've played pretty much every fishing game I came across on various game platforms since my Vic-20 and Sega Genesis days, and have a fairly good background in various types of Sportfishing.  I also specialized in Fish & Wildlife Management Technology in College after graduating from the Forestry Technician program at Sault College in Ontario, Canada.  All that should suggest that I REALLY enjoy fishing and studying various fish species.I was hesitant to download and try World of Fishing, until last week that is.  After playing Carp Fishing Simulator, EuroFishing, and Fishing Planet in the last year I wasn't all that interested in trying a cartoon-looking Fishing MMO with combat and pvp.  Say what?.  Boy, was I ever wrong about the fun factor of this F2P Fishing MMO, at least the FreeFishing Style which is all I've played to date.  There's team play, team vs team, or 4vs1 if you are Poseidon or the Kraken.You really don't need to buy anything at all to enjoy playing this addictive fishing game.  But if you end up enjoying it as much as I have (like playing 6-7hrs straight at a time enjoyment) you will find it real easy to validate spending money to get some of the extras you can buy.  But again, if you don't want to spend a dime, you still will have some serious fishing game fun, I can guarantee you that.Make a character, choose the look with gender, clothes, fishing gear, boats, and even some helper navigators.  You'll need them for boating and sailing around the HUGE oceans and waterways across the Globe.  That's right!  There are areas all over this lovely planet of ours in the game with so many varied species of fish, some I'm sure you've never seen or heard of before.So many quests and areas to unlock with either completing questlines from zone to zone as you progress, or just jumping ahead once you attain the level required.  A great challenge when your Lvl.18 character goes up against fish that are lvl.49 or more while using Lvl.15 gear.  Not too difficult to master if you use the 'attack swings', hold techniques, and of course your boat to close the gap or increase that gap with the fish.  It will still be a great fish battle and when it's over, you'll have tons of XP and one hell of a fish to put in your personal aquarium.  Feel free to embelish your fishing stories also, I know I do.Any aquariums you ask?  Yes indeed there is.  Probably the 2nd biggest factor that has me hooked on this game.  As you fish, level up, upgrade your boat's livewell amongst other things, you'll want to start a nice collection of the most impressive and big trophy fish you've caught.  There's so many fish species in the game that you'll be creating and building your own 'Fish Wiki' as you catch new and bigger specimens, including secret and rare ones.  Lots of room for them in your aquarium, and you can sell the specimens you don't wish to keep anymore, directly to the fish market from your aquarium menu.I've also noticed that there are actual GMs on all the time, and they launch surprise GM Events all through the day including XP Boosts, or much higher drop rates for Lucky Cards which give you a chance to roll on 1:5 random store items.I have so many more details and personal online fishing experiences to share from my short time playing the game already, but this "Review" is already a hefty blah, blah, blah fest, so I'll leave it at that for now.The TLDR version of this is:Awesomely addictive fishing game (fun GAME... not simulator per say) that will surely have you playing at least for 2hrs real time each time you log in, or 6hrs with the 2x 2hr extensions you can add to your fishing trip.  Of course nothing stops you from going out on another trip when the current one expires.  Although, you will get friendly reminders on how much time you've played and will be advised to take a short break.  After a 7hrs straight stretch on my fishing trip, the game was basically begging me to stop playing and to go for a walk or something. heheIt's FREE 100% fun...but you'll want to spend some money just because it's fun as hell and want the game to continue on and on.Thanks for reading, and may your line tension be steady.

												Alright so clear things up a little bit, i've played this game through the primary client for some time now (probably close to a year at this point with a little less than 500 hours in it.) And need to make a few things very clear about getting into this game. IT'S NOT A FAST PACED GAME! Do not come into this thinking it'll be a quick and adventurous thing! If you do that, then of course it's going to feel like crap!*Boat controls are sluggish, much like a real boat's reaction time when it comes to pontoon vehicles, *there is drift, *off limits fishing zones, *slow trips to the zone you're going to, Level-based (edited)***limited baits for those that aren't paying customers (which is fine if you're not a severe fan of fishing and only play for fun.) All bait is indeed purchaseable with ingame currency, it's just a question of patience and devotion to keep playing if you plan to keep up with demand when it comes to bait up-keep.*It's a bit tough to get started in this game, If you've played the fishing minigame from GaiaOnline (or played the mobile game "Ace Fishing: Wild Catch"... or hell ANY fishing game from the last 20 years, including from the old-school Sega system, Rapala, Cavela's, Championship Bass etc.)  then you're already pretty much prepped to play this game. Your best bet is to take heed to the tutorial, take a bit in a public lobby and just chat while you fish. It's always better to converse with others than sit alone. :)SIGNING UP!Signing up for this game is a little more tedious than others, as there is no "connecting" Steam to the primary, which means you'll need an account either on the actual account, or an account on steam (or in my case now, an account on both but only one is my actual account now.) This doesn't mean that it's hard to make an account, you just need different accounts for Steam and the actual launcher :/ so if you play through Steam, use the account you signed up using the "register" button in its sign-up page of the launcher.If you signed up through the launcher that is downloaded from their website or through their main website page you'll need to play through their actual launcher/game. not steamNow another thing that needs to be addressed is the lack of a help desk. Yes, this is an issue. And so is the issue with no way for disgruntled players to really get help in this game. Forums are always negative due to the fact that no one really takes the time to think before they type (as many of these reviews show.Do i suggest this game? Of course! :) It's a great time-passer. If you prefer mobile games though i suggest "Ace Fishing: Wild Catch" (albeit that game relies on a daily energy limit but it can be ignored if you got plenty of friends to send you energy, since you can overload the limit ;)Edit: Adjusted some mentions in this review due to my poorly written comment about the bait, added a bit to the starting out part as well. I'll look to add to the review as i settle back into playing it now that i've switched over to Steam from the standalone launcher varient. But for now? it's time to sleep. happy new-year everyone <3

												Ok, so lets start out by saying that yes, i played maybe 5 min before thinking of uninstalling this game, and no, it wasnt unresponsive servers at all.I thought it might be a nice fishing game opposite of say Fishing Planet, and honestly expected a similar realistic gameplay. Instead i got a asian styled arcade game with bad character design and even worse voice overs. The tutorial made me imediatly kringe when the voice over started telling me how to play the game, and when i finaly did cast out and caught a fish, it started saying how awsome i was for catching a scripted fish in a tutorial, KRINGE. As for the rest, reeling in a fish amounts to nothing more then watching 3 status bars and managing them in order to reduce the fish his StreetFighter'esc stamina(health)bar down to zero, all the while the actual fish not moving at all in the water. Arcade, thats what this game is, a arcade like fishing game. So yeah, to sum it up;Graphics: 4/10Graphics are terrible for this age, even for a mmo. Screenshots above do NOT represend the true graphical scale at all, since bellow the watterline there is absolutely zero interesting textures, just plain sand coloured contours of the bodem. Sure, it isnt something like Jedi Knight series of games bad (check them out on google to get a picture) but hardly up to standard for a mmo these days. Infact, ive seen indie games with better graphics design than this. Gameplay: 4/10"The most realistic fishing MMO of the world" it says in th trailer. If thats the case, then i supose that next time i go out fishing in RL, i actualy need to only watch out for 3 bars that tell me how tired the fish is while its just hanging still there in the water. Yeah, not realy realistic, sure tention, fish stamina, it is all part of real life fishing, but the way its implemented here, there is no thrill in pulling in a big fish.Music: 1/10First thing in i did was shut the damn music up. Given, i usualy hate the loud repetetive music in most games, but this was realy bad. Voice overs: 3/10Like i said in the above paragraph, the voice overs are kringe worthy. The actor who spoke the tutorial part just sounded like he read his lines from a paper sheet while bored out of his mind. It had no actual feeling in it, like he was forcing himeself to do the lines, but realy didnt like doing it. Character design: 3/10You can create your own character....................but you cant realy customize it at all. Sure you can buy hair and clothing, but you cant truly change how you look. Per sex (Male/Female obviously) you have 5 presets to choice from, then are promted to give it a name. Thats all there is to it. Oh, and the clothes and stuff, yeah..........your stuck in an ugly shirt an shorts untill you fork over real money for those, cause they are bought with premium coins called pearls. This is not even mentioning the cliché npc's that can contact you for quests. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------So bottom line, this game is not a good game if you realy like fishing to be more then a arcady styled anime cliché, but are more into realistic fishing simulaters. Which is also where i say, that the claim they make to be a "unique mix of Fishing Simulation and full-fledged MMO" is a complete farce.

YouTube™ Video: First Impressions | World of Fishing 

			Views: 167		

			We take a look at the first hour of the new Fishing MMO 'World of Fishing', free-to-play on Steam. Website: http://www.2PLYR.com Watch Live: http://twitch.tv/2PLYR Twitter: http://twitter.com/twoPLYR...		

World of Fishing is a fishing 'MMO', a very interesting and unique concept. Although free to play, I haven't yet hit the typical paywalls or daily limits that usually come with F2P games. The main limiter here is your boats fuel which is used to drive from area to area looking for the different species of fish needed to complete quests. While not exactly an MMO in the sense of grouping with people towards a goal, there are some player-to-player interactions available.Pros:Fun and relaxing.Very unique and original concept that is well thought out.While the skill/stat tree is basic, there seems to be an abundance of options as far as items go. Clothing, accessories, rods, reels, boats, aquariums and more are all available for purchase with in-game money (Shells) or your own money (Pearls).No heavy paywalls preventing further progression each day, barring you don't play for more than 3-5 hours per day.Cons:Since launch there are some server issues and lag in-game. They are actively working to bring on additional servers to handle the load however.Some items, such as underwater cameras, only appear to be purchasable with the cash shop currency instead of earned in-game currency.There are some grammatical and spelling errors that can make it difficult to understand some aspects of the game's features in the beginning.Overally, definitely worth trying, especially as a F2P game. A very unique and fun experience.
